title: Friday, 11th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
PM

Morning

PM

Respectfully late this morning

PM

I've got a confession to make, so I'll make it up front

11:04 am
PM

I'm completely baffled by market movements this week

PM

Completely baffled

PM

I get that there's the so called reflation trade

11:04 am
PM

And all this switching out of so called bond proxies

PM

But for London and New York to go in exactly the opposite direction -- that's actually really rare

PM

Anyway

11:05 am
PM

While you're pondering that

PM

Can I just say that I love Matt Taibbi's prose

BE

Best writer currently writing. Agree.

11:06 am
PM

Rudy Giuliani, probably too unhinged by now for even a People's Court reboot, might be attorney general. God only knows who might end up being Supreme Court nominees; we can only hope they turn out to be lawyers, or at least people who played lawyers onscreen. And sitting behind this fun-house nightmare of executive-branch worthies (which Politico speculates will be one of the more "eclectic" cabinets ever) will be a rubber-stamping all-Republican legislature that will attract the loving admiration of tinhorn despots from Minsk to Beijing.

PM

http://www.rolling...t-so-wrong-w449783

PM

Everyone gets it in the neck there

11:06 am

Including Taibbi himself

PM

Do have a read of that later.

undefined

So come on Bryce, unbaffle me

BE

Right then! Here we go!

BE

Great!

BE

So stuff like utilities, REITs and financials we can mostly ignore, as we can pin to the steepening of the yield curve

There's the n the emerging market selloff, which is on the unpredictable second-order response to the dollar's rally.

So we've had a gigantic selloff of EM bonds, which means this happens.

11:11 am
BE

But it tells us very little about what people think a Trump-shaped world will actually look like.

BE

For that, we can try and extrapolate something from the Bloomberg World index, a benchmark of 3000 global stocks or thereabouts, grouped into industries.

BE

So dollar adjusted, these are the post-Election winners:

11:11 am
BE

Aerospace and defence (up 5.3%)

BE

Pharmaceuticals (up 4.5%), biotech (up 8.7%, top performing sector).

BE

Coal miners (up 2.2%). Iron and steel production (up 5.2%).

11:12 am
BE

As these are the losers ...

BE

Food (4.3%), agriculture (down 5.7%), beverages (down 5.2%) and food service (down 6.3%, worst performing sector).

BE

Cosmetics and personal care (down 5.6%). Household products (down 4.9%), housewares (down 3.3%) and apparel (down 2.1%).

11:12 am
BE

Internet (down 3.7%). Semiconductors (down 3.5%). Software (down 2.2%). Hardware (down 1.9%).

PM

That's really useful Bryce

BE

It is kinda useful, but not terribly optimistic.

11:12 am
BE

It says a Trump presidency looks bad for soap, food and technological progress.

BE

But it's excellent if you want to take some drugs, then go shoot some foreigners in the face and extract their minerals.

BE

Oh, and also .....

11:13 am
BE

The global toys, hobbies and games index is down 1.6%.

BE

The global office furniture index is up 5.1%.

BE

That's our future. That's where we are.

11:13 am
BE

Desks, not Lego.

PM

hehehehe

undefined
11:13 am
PM

Some big strat notes coming through

PM

From the likes of Themos Fiotakis at UBS

PM

I will share the cover page

11:14 am
PM

And I promise to do a LR pack

PM

Later

PM

Fiscal easing: How much hope is in the price?

11:14 am
PM

Markets have moved to price game-changer fiscal easing…
In principle, significant fiscal easing in the US economy could represent a structural
break for global bonds, stocks and the dollar. The post GFC years have seen structurally
low rates of growth and inflation globally. While monetary policy has been the major
driver for markets, in terms of its economic impact, it has mainly relied on lifting
inflation expectations. For a number of reasons, this task has proven unattainable. The
closer we edge towards a global liquidity trap, it is possible under certain conditions for
expansionary fiscal policy to support growth and raise interest rates, equity earnings
expectations and the dollar, especially if combined with broad business-friendly policies.

PM

…but the devil lies in the details (and the size).
Having said this, fiscal easing is no panacea. There are fiscal outcomes that may even
end up having opposite results than the ones originally intended. At the very least, and
from a high level and highly stylized perspective, we would need to see broad progrowth
measures of meaningful size and scale. It would need to involve measures with
meaningful growth impact (including structural and regulatory interventions). And any
calculation on asset impact would need to take into account the side-effects of higher
borrowing costs (at least in terms of higher term premia).

PM

Exploring the market impact of each trillion dollars spent.
We examine two highly stylized and symmetric scenarios to benchmark the asset
market effects of each one trillion dollars spent over a decade. In the first scenario we
assume that measures of low growth impact are deployed; here, bond yields are
projected to rise by a total of about 50bps, while equities are projected to decline by a
total of 5%. In the second scenario, we assume measures of high growth impact are
deployed; in this case yields rise by more than 100bps, equities rally by 10% in the
medium term and the dollar rallies by 3% against majors (e.g., the EUR). Again, these
are stylized scenarios, the main purpose of which is to capture a broad spectrum of
possibilities. They are not meant to predict the most likely effects on growth.

11:15 am
PM

What to do
At the time of writing, there is little certainty about the size, composition and areas of
deployment of fiscal resources by the new US administration. Nevertheless, markets
have moved to price a structural break; US bond yields have risen by 30bps, US equities
are up by about 4% and the USD is up by 1.4% against the EUR. These moves are
premature in terms of macro foundations. But we would not fade them yet.
Relative to the scenarios we simulated, the market is not yet pricing outlandish
outcomes. We will be watching for the levels that would indicate such exuberance or
for macro evidence that either confirm or challenge the current market assumptions.

PM

Note: premature in terms of macro foundations.

PM

A few words on methodology and a few caveats
This is a preliminary and high-level exercise that gauges the outcomes markets are
pricing in. The results of this exercise will inevitably get recalibrated once we get more
details on the actual fiscal plan. To produce our results we use the frameworks we
deployed in Big Macro 01, 02, 03 and 04. We estimate the effects of $1tn worth of
additional net issuance on term premia, we estimate the impact of stronger trend
growth on equilibrium real rates and the impact of shifts in rate expectations and term
premia on equities. Lastly, we use our own "optimal control" methodology to project
the impact of fiscal easing on Fed policy and then on the dollar. These frameworks
capture a deep enough degree of complexity to produce plausible estimates. That said,
reality is much more complex; for instance we have made no assumptions on the
impact of new policies on trade (which could skew these results to the downside).

11:16 am
PM

And, while we're at it, Jonathan Stubbs from Citi

PM

Post-Trump: QE+, Regime Change, Reflation, Rotation, Risks

PM

Republican sweep
Another victory for Vox Populi (Citi Chief Political Analyst Tina Fordham’s key theme). Another loss for the establishment/status quo. A rare clean sweep could afford the new President greater scope to deliver his campaign agenda of tax cuts and expansionary spending. But, success is not guaranteed and US political risk remains.
QE+ and the ‘Fiscal Hedge’
This week provides more evidence of what we have called QE+ in recent months, ie a broadening of the post GFC (global) policy put away from monetary (QE) to monetary & fiscal (QE+). This is why we have also specifically highlighted the need, in recent months, for investors to have a ‘fiscal hedge’. We raised Construction to Overweight in July 2016 to reflect this and also highlighted infrastructure and military spend as other key components of this hedge.

11:16 am
PM

Regime change
Markets have reflected an investment community aggressively invested into realized downside macro risks, via bonds and equity Low Risk. Little notice of inflation hedging = dangerous. A Trump win, one way or another, is likely to signal regime change: a) US fiscal easing or b) protectionism. Bond moves reflect the sense of ‘regime change’. While recognizing risks, we continue to align with higher bond yields/inflation expectations and to higher 2017E EPS growth in 2017.
Reflation & rotation
Citi’s Rate Strategist, Harvinder Sian, sees a Trump win allied to a Republican clean sweep as bearish for global bond markets and expects fiscal expansion to trump “fuzzy concerns” on global trade/security. We broadly agree. Harvinder expects bear steepening to dominate. In turn, this is likely to fuel further rotation across equity markets with Financials, Commodities & Cyclicals as key beneficiaries and Defensives, Low Risk & Quality acting as source of funds.

PM

Three pain trades
We have highlighted three pain trades: 1) equities vs bonds, 2) Value, 3) European banks. Bond investors in Japan, UK, Germany and the US have now all suffered 10% losses in short order from 30-year government bonds. Not risk free. This means lower returns, lower Sharpe ratios and less willing buyers. Value continues to look cheap in equity markets and is the only quant style likely to benefit from higher bond yields. Bear steepening and improving bank fundamentals support our start-October move to Overweight in European banks.
Risks
There are always risks. These need assessing and managing. Recently, we have suggested that too many investors have been driven by passive Risk Management, eg capital protection strategies, instead of active Risk Management, eg inflation hedging. What are key risks now? Upside equity risk remains a key risk for us. But, we are not one-eyed. We also see regime change impacting previous macro relationships between oil prices, inflation expectations, bond yields and the USD. European political risk cannot be ignored; next up Italy, then France etc.

PM

There's another 22 pages of that

11:17 am
PM

Again, I promise to do a LR pack

undefined
BE

Couple more things before we move onto the grit of the UK market.

11:19 am
BE

First, Tony Dwyer at Canaccord seems quite annoyed by the common idea that the massive surge in the US Treasury yield says anything bad whatsoever about the US economic outlook.

BE

Myth – Large spikes in US Treasury yields are bad for stocks. Wednesday saw a record
rise of 11% in the U.S. Treasury yield following Trump’s election. The new bear thought
process is that a still easy Fed and likelihood of increased fiscal stimulus might cause
growth to be too good, which would lead to higher inflation and interest rates.

BE

Reality – Large spikes in rates do NOT precede recessions or sustained periods of
market weakness. With the help of our “stats dude” at Sundial Capital, we looked for
the initial instances of a one-day gain of greater than 5% in the UST yield (Figure 1). In
the seven prior occurrences since 1962, we would observe the following:
• The S&P 500 (SPX) was up every time six months later, with median 7% gain (Figure
1).
• The most recent occurrence period (2013) saw the UST yield ultimately climb to 3% by
year end from initial spike, while the S&P 500 rose 23% (Figure 2).
• The Dwyer Strategy “Offensive Sector” Index outperforms the “Defensive Sector” Index
by a wide margin (Figure 3).
• It never indicated a recession was looming. Two instances saw the spikes while exiting
a recession (1980, 2009).
• In all cases, UST yield had already turned higher following a dramatic decline.
• UST yield performance was mixed with downward bias in the month following the spike
day (Figure 4).

11:20 am
BE

Let me get those figs.

BE

BE

11:21 am
BE

PM

Isn't it tricky doing comparisons here when the 'spike' is from such a low base?

BE

Well, yes. It is.

11:22 am
BE

I'm seeing this whole argument as kinda unconvincing, but I share it anyway because we're a broad church.

11:25 am
BE

Jefferies is house broker.

BE

To reflect the weakening trading conditions reported by the Board this morning, we are reducing our FY2016 PBT estimates by 18% from £91.4m to £75.3m, the lower end of today's guidance.

BE

With the announcement of a change of CEO and CFO in the space of one month, uncertainty around the start date of the incoming CFO and the search for a new CEO starting today, there is no current guidance for FY2017. We have therefore cut our FY2017 estimates to match the existing Board's guidance for FY2016, a cut of 26% from £101.7m to £76m.

11:26 am
BE

In the face of such uncertainty, we can no longer recommend that investors buy the shares. With such a large cut to estimates, we expect short-term share price weakness, and until the uncertainty around the structure and arrival of the top management team and Board is known, the price of the shares is likely, in our view, to exhibit higher-than-usual levels of volatility. The volatility in the price of the shares we expect also makes it difficult for us to recommend investors sell the shares. Whether wishing to buy or sell shares, we advise waiting until the dust has settled in order to more accurately appraise the future cashflows on which the valuation is ultimately based.

PM

goodness

BE

And Davy.

11:27 am
BE

The revised pre-tax profit guidance is very significantly below the current FactSet
consensus estimate of £92m (Davy: £98m). It implies an underlying pre-tax profit of
around £28-33m in H2, which would be 27-38% behind that delivered in the second
half of 2015 (£46m). SIG has suggested that gross margins year-to-date contracted 30
basis points (bps), having been down only 10 bps in H1. Hence the pressure on
underlying revenues is clearly exacerbated by a very severe margin squeeze.

BE

The 1.1% decline in LFL revenues in the UK and Ireland between July and October
compares with growth of 2.3% in the first half of the year. According to SIG, market
conditions have weakened as competition has intensified. SIG specifically has been
affected by delays in some commercial projects and “subdued demand” for technical
insulation in the petrochemical and manufacturing sectors.
SIG has also revealed that its offsite construction business has been impacted by the
delay in the commissioning of new plant and machinery. This has pushed some projects
into 2017. All this would suggest a very sharp erosion in UK profits in the second half of
the year.

BE

Trends and commentary in relation to Mainland Europe are not as bleak. LFL revenues
fell 0.5% in Mainland Europe between July and October. This was actually a bit better
than the H1 performance (-1.2%). This looks to be due to an improved performance in
France, where LFL revenues fell 1% in the July to October months compared with 3.6%
in H1. In Germany, where a new management team is in place, LFL revenues fell 0.9%
between July and October (H1: -1.9%).

11:28 am
BE

Not seeing that much readthrough for the sector, which I guess it because SIG warned this time last year as well.

BE

(I don't understand why inflation's good for supermarkets. I don't understand why people keep saying that. I understand why deflation's bad for them, and that higher prices are a positive if they're not matched by higher costs, but not why any inflation's automatically good. This is why I'd never make it as an analyst.)

11:35 am
BE

At a guess, I think Next and Sainsbury (as in Argos) is a dolalr trade as much as anything.

BE

As per RBC earlier in the week ............

BE

The stocks with the biggest exposure are Hugo Boss (17%), ASOS (13%), H&M (12%) and ABF (8%). However the sector has significant USD sourcing exposure, particularly apparel retailers like H&M, Next and M&S. Thus any general short-term USD weakness versus the SEK and £ respectively would lower their purchasing costs and would be a small positive on a relative basis.
Medium term our currency strategists believe that we may see broad USD strength via the potential for a tax cut on retained earnings abroad. As such this could create further cost inflationary pressure for retailers with high USD sourcing exposure which would pose a risk to gross margins and potentially to volumes if this cost pressure is passed onto consumers.

11:37 am
BE

And Jefferies.

BE

General retail as a whole should be mostly a net winner from a softer US$, with all UK
names benefiting, especially SPD (virtually all US$ sourced), DEB and NXT (MKS is less
of a beneficiary given food in the mix). DNLM and BME are also major beneficiaries given
large amount of US$ sourced homewares. At the harder end of the sector, the net benefit
is less profound at KGF and DFS given more European based supply chains, especially
at the former. The net impact is a less obvious positive at ABF, with reducing sourcing
pressures at Primark more than balanced out by translation downgrades elsewhere in the
group (and is the potential development of a Mexican-based supply chain to support US
ambitions impacted?) ITX is the only named directly exposed to the sharp MXP sell-off
(but note we estimate the overnight c.15% sell-off in €MXN to translate into a limited 0.7%
cut to our group estimates); whether Trump's presidency results in a consistently weaker
EM currencies world (ITX is approx one-third EM biased) is the key question. ITX's direct
exposure to US sales remains small, but at HMB US sales account for c.13% of group total.
The potential negative impact on translation should be largely neutralised by a devaluing
US$ to € rate, given the extent to which still predominantly European earned cashflows fund largely US$ denominated purchases. We see limited impact at MDM, even if we see some sourcing benefits from US$ devaluation.

BE

All of which is deeply out of date now, when markets made an absolute fool of us all, but you can reverse engineer the logic.

11:38 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 325.00, up 8.2 (+2.59%), High: 325.40, Low: 315.70, Volume: 3.86m

11:45 am
undefined

What about BATS.

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 4,353, up 94 (+2.21%), High: 4,364, Low: 4,237, Volume: 2.45m
11:46 am
PM

What about BATs

BE

That's a bounce. It was sold off quite aggressively over the past couple of days because of the yield curve, quasi bond thing.

BE

Which is a bit tricky for BATS as it's currently trying to shove a lot of sterling-denominated stock at Americans in exchange for the rest of Reynolds.

11:47 am
BE

The more BATS falls, the greater the chances of a bump.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse to talk us through the maths.

BE

Since BAT announced its proposal to buy out the outstanding 58% of
Reynolds (20th October), its share price has fallen 12%, of which 2% can be
explained by a slightly stronger £ (as hopes of a 'soft' Brexit have risen).
Reflecting the FX, we lower our EPS by 2% and price target to £51.75.

11:48 am
BE

In our view, some of the weakness is a result of investors selling BAT to buy
Reynolds. As almost 60% of the proposed consideration is in the form of BAT
shares, the lower the BAT share price, the greater the likelihood the terms
may have to be sweetened. The Reynolds share price has almost exactly
tracked the implied offer valuation which has fallen 5%. At the same time
10yr US treasury yields have risen 30bp post-election which has exerted
severe downward pressure on 'bond-proxy' equities and suggests greater
downside to the Reynolds share price should the deal not happen. The
Reynolds board is currently considering its reaction to BAT's proposal.

BE

They remain positive tho.

BE

Whilst we believe it might have been better if BAT had waited 12 months
(when we suspect the operating environment for US tobacco will not be as
favorable), we see a strategic and financial logic to the deal. It is relatively
low risk, synergistic, EPS accretive and reduces FX transaction volatility.
■ BAT trades on a FY17 PE of 14.6x; a 25% discount to the staples sector and
a 20% discount to close peer PMI. We find the latter particularly difficult to
justify given the imminent launch (in Japan) of BAT's new generation product
(glo), which appears to be very competitive with PMI's iQOS product.

11:49 am
BE

BE

[A] significant proportion of BAT's volumes are in markets where
the [retail] price elasticity of demand is below 0.7, which gives it scope to
sustain high single digit earnings growth as retail prices continue to rise. We
believe BAT will outperform the staples sector over the next 12 months.

BE

Dunno. Doesn't look that defensive to me either way.

BE

Sellside wise, we have Trader Gordon at Investec selling Barclays.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 201.15, up 0.05 (+0.02%), High: 205.00, Low: 198.40, Volume: 26.19m
11:59 am
BE

Quite valuation-y.

BE

From a banking perspective, we warmly welcome the outcome of the US Presidential election, believing it has the potential to encourage a more even-handed approach to regulation. Barclays shares have already responded, +8% in 2 days.

We note the initial impact on yield curves (which we see as essentially positive for most banks). We also see Barclays as a clear beneficiary from a strong dollar, (in terms of Sterling translation of Dollar earnings) and our (unchanged) house view that a stronger dollar will be broadly sustained. We currently expect £/$ to trade in a 1.18-1.27 range through 2017.

BE

"A more even-handed approach to regulation" ............ Yes, okay.

12:00 pm
BE

Sticking Dimon into a Treasury job would certainly lead to even-handedness.

PM

(Do you buy this Dimon idea? Not sure I do.)

BE

(No, I doubt Dimon would go for it. He's too similar to Trump except smart.)

12:02 pm
PM

(exactly)

BE

(Pulling in the world's most prominent Wall Street banker might also look a wee bit contractionary when Trump ran a campaign that hinted in pretty broad terms that the banking industry is run by a zionist cabal. But I digress .......)

BE

Back to Gordon.

12:03 pm
BE

However, the simple truth is that despite modest upward revisions to our forecasts, the outlook for returns still paints a moderately underwhelming picture. Barclays’ UK division has delivered zero loan growth over the past 12 months, and we perceive that management has limited appetite to change this.

To give credit where credit is due, we think CEO Jes Staley’s decision to retain a refocused “transatlantic” Investment Bank was correct. Cost efficiency improvements have come through largely in line with our forecasts. However we fear that the subtle shift away from absolute cost reduction targets towards a more traditional focus on the cost:income ratio could blunt delivery here.

BE

Our EPS forecast in 2018e increases by 3% to 22.5p, some 17% ahead of Bloomberg consensus (19.3p). However, despite modest (upward) revisions, we still forecast RoTEs of only 3%, 5% and 7% through 2016-18e.

We downgrade to Hold (from Buy). Our TP is raised to 210p (from 200p), but this affords insufficient upside to sustain a Buy recommendation. We recommend a switch into Aldermore, Shawbrook and OneSavings (all Buys).
